description:
My cousin wanted to try this place out and since we all love sushi, it was perfect!

It's the cutest thing ever. You order on the touch screen and the food gets delivered by a "train". My son loved telling me to push the button to send it back. It was such a new exciting experience for everyone!

The CA rolls was good. The dragon roll was delicious. I didn't get to try the Rock n Roll cause my man ate it all! He claimed it was delicious...  I bet it was! Seriously everything was surprisingly really good. My cousin ordered squid, fried won tons, and something with an egg or custard, idk. The mango green tea was good. 

I would mosdef just come back and eat here again! Customer service was on point. They even had two TVs playing kids shows which both of our kids watch! Like Oddbods! The place was nice and clean too.
author: Yee W.

description:
The first time I came to this restaurant I loved it! The train concept was super fun and servers were really friendly- although I think they've grown a lot and they get super busy so maybe they don't know how to manage it anymore. 
Last couple times I've been there I always get really annoyed about service- even tho I request help on the screen I will always have to catch someone while they walk by cause they just won't came otherwise... I stress to the point that I don't get to enjoy my meal. For example, I have to wait a long time for plates, new sticks or spoons, even when my food has already arrived and it's getting cold. I always tell myself I won't comeback but the sushi is not bad and the location is really good and when I'm hungry I think I can put up with it.  I work on a restaurant and I would advice them to get someone to work as a busser, because the line is always super long even when there's several tables empty just because no one has time to clean them! - I'm not opposed to wait, since I understand what they're going through, but sometimes is just too much. Same happens while we're eating there, plates will pile up and I will have to ask several times for them to be removed.
I'm trying to be friendly and just advising some things me and my friends have noticed because the sushi and food is actually pretty good and we would love to come to this spot if this things improve.
author: Barbara D.

description:
After coming out of Japantown mall and crossing to the other side of Post St., I noticed that this new sushi bar was opened.  Indeed, it's Hikari (Dawn), San Francisco's first bullet train sushi, the next conveyor belt sushi bar of the future!  After asking a couple of staff about this brand new sushi bar, I find it very interesting before I took my leave.

By Saturday, it's better to take this opportunity to try out any of their iPad after I was seated almost next to a whacky middle aged woman on my right side.  A pair of nigiri wasn't my aim in the bullet train sushi bar; therefore, I haven't touched the wasabi and a pickled ginger.  Miso soup wasn't always my signature starter since I closed it off to make way for soba noodle soup bowl with ebi kakiage.  Potato croquette?  I closed the frenchy one I chose before and picked the grilled mushrooms as my appetizer.  Dragging unto the right hand iPad screen to get to warabi matcha, and I have up to three selections out of four before I'm done.

First up, speeding towards my right destination was my grilled mushrooms!  Tasted smoky when chewing the mushroom flavor and it's so good than it was once bland.  Next up, warabi matcha of the dessert section!  These mochi cubes covered in matcha powder and lathered with Japanese black honey are truly a sweet treat which I saved the best for last.  Finally, a soba noodle bowl and ebi kakiage, only be delivered to me by the hands of the male wait staff.  While the mini bowl of soba noodle was good as warm, I love the crunchiness of the battered tempura shrimp and vegetables mixed together.

Eating in Hikari was great!  There are plenty of things I want to bring up about my experience here.  When tapping on the iPad for the right selections, there's no time limit and I can change the selections back.  Whenever I need help with the self service features, I asked for any wait staff or I asked one of the customers on my left or right side.  Food service was as quick as the 200 mph bullet train.  Every time the red button blinked and sounded, that means my food came to my right destination.  Tap the flashing red button, and the bullet train goes backward towards the kitchen area.  Best customer service!  Highly recommended!    ^_^
author: Jimmy C.

description: Their Food and Service had improved from the first time we ate here.. few Months after they opened.. their Bullet Train Food Delivery is a good treat for the Kids.. you can do small portions at a very Reasonable price . The friendly computer monitor when you order .. your food comes out on a cute Bullet train ... I strongly suggest this place for patrons who has kids
author: Donovan L.

description:
I hear the train a-comin'
It's rollin' 'round the bend
And I ain't seen the sunshine
Since I don't know when
I'm here sittin' in Hikari
And time keeps draggin' on...

Johnny Cash was great, wasn't he? Anyway, as I was passing by on a quiet Tuesday evening, I wasn't sure about trying this place because it struck me as just a locomotive variation on the sushi boat concept. When I entered the almost-empty space, I was cordially led to the long counter against the wall where I was staring at an iPad with a sliding pictorial menu (photo: http://bit.ly/2odUFaV). I also noticed two sets of tracks that ran back into the kitchen, so I assumed the bullet train was riding those rails.

I took it from there since I'm Asian and don't require instructions. The menu was pretty standard for a J-Town sushi restaurant. I started with my litmus test, the variety-pack Chirashi which came as an $18 Dinner Set with miso soup. Ironically a server brought me the generic soup (photo: http://bit.ly/2MXF9xY), but it dawned on me that there was the risk of a miso tsunami if it travelled at full speed on the train. My chirashi box did come on the 8:20 from Osaka complete with sound effects.

Frankly it was a middling combo of medium-quality fish highlighted by a lot of roe with a bed of slightly overcooked rice (photo: http://bit.ly/2MTIKwV). I pressed the red button to send the train back. You would think that would be enough, but I also ordered a $7 plate of Ankimo, three slices of monkfish liver that tasted a bit on the dry side (photo: http://bit.ly/2LxXQTW). The best thing I had was the $3 Teba, which are chicken wings served up as yakitori (photo: http://bit.ly/2PJaqmz). The bullet train must have had a hypnotic effect on me (video: http://bit.ly/2P9N1K4) because...

For reasons unknown, I came back a couple of weeks later to try some of the other items. My other litmus test was the $13 Hamachi Kama which came on the 7:45 from Nagoya overcooked and a little too charred (photo: http://bit.ly/2LxAVbl). I also tried the $6 Hamachi Sashimi, which struck me as pricey for three slices (photo: http://bit.ly/2wm48RQ), and the $3 Negima, a rather skimpy version of chicken yakitori (photo: http://bit.ly/2LxXjkU). The $2.50 Matcha Pudding was the last bullet train home to Yokohama, but it refused to deliver above the school cafeteria level (photo: http://bit.ly/2NpKbQN).

FOOD - 3 stars...too much focus on transportation appears to mean less on the quality of the fish
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...certainly spacious enough though where's the clickety-clack, rotating train schedule?
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...they work in the background and let the train create the 'magic'
TOTAL - 3 stars...I hear the train a-comin'

RELATED - Looking for more dining options in Japantown? Here's a list of the places I've tried and reviewed: http://bit.ly/2MjfL6j
author: Ed U.

description: I like the unique concept of having food delivered by a robotic bullet train (shinkansen in Japanese), but the food was just ok. I ordered a chicken katsu curry udon; the chicken was fried nicely, but the udon and curry had a bland flavor. ($11). I did enjoy the fatty tuna sushi ($6). Service was very friendly and not crowded for Friday lunch.
author: Thomas L.

description:
There's a new Japanese spot in Japantown, and it markets myself as the first bullet train sushi spot in San Francisco!

There's an iPad located at each booth and individual seat, and all ordering is done through the iPad. They have a wide selection of Japanese dishes, including appetizers, sushi rolls, nigiri, rice bowls, etc. You can only place up to 4 orders at a time, and the food comes served to your seat via a bullet train shaped plate. Pretty nifty :)

I came for Sunday lunch around noon and there were plenty of empty booths and seats. We ordered a variety of dishes and shared everything. My favorites were the karaage ($6), which had the right amount of crispiness and batter, and the gyoza ($6), which even my picky friend admitted was good, but their sushi rolls were solid as well. Also, we got a dessert (matcha cheesecake) on the house, which was sweet of them!

Once we ordered enough dishes, a fun screen popped up on the iPad and we had to choose one of three treasure boxes. Not sure what else you can win, but we won an order of salmon nigiri! I thought it would be some toy, similar to what you can win at Kula down in south bay, but I like the idea of winning food a lot better :)

I also appreciated that prices were on par with your typical Japanese joint; I was half expecting things to extra pricey here due to the bullet train concept and its prime location in Japantown. We each paid ~$25 for the meal, which isn't bad at all.

The only thing is that it can slightly awkward to order, as there are multiple pages to scroll through, and really only the two people closest to the iPad can order, but other than that, it was a fun lunch experience!
author: Dianna H.

description:
TRAINS! I shouted to my Woof as we entered into Hikari. I happened across this place from a random advertisement that popped up one day and I absolutely loved the concept, and on a Saturday afternoon, we decided to give it a shot!

Hikari is a pretty good sized restaurant with the draw that it is (as far as I know?) the only bullet train restaurant in SF. Basically, you order via a little iPad device at your table, and then when your food is ready, a cute little Choo drives out to your table and drops off your food for you! 

We ended up going for some different nigiri and a roll, and soon our little locomotive was out to our table! Not just a gimmick restaurant, but actually really high quality and fresh fish!

Prices are very reasonable which is saying a lot given this is a place in Japantown. Friendly staff, and fun idea!

Note: you need to send the train back by pressing the red button or else it will scream an alarm at you over and over! 

Two paws up from me!
author: Jei C.

description:
Love love love the concept. The food is very good and fresh. Tasty teas by the way. Would definitely come back!
Update: i love love love the shrimp tempura here!!! So good
author: Giang L.

description:
Hikari prides itself on being San Francisco's first bullet train sushi restaurant, however, the execution of this fails to reach the standard already set in the Bay Area by Kula.

Being big fans of the novelty and fun of bullet train sushi, the boyfriend and I decided to try having dinner here with some friends since we were in Japantown at the New People building next door. We thought they would be extremely busy at dinner time on a weekend, but there was actually plenty of space inside and we got to choose whether we wanted to sit at a booth or at the bar (opted for the latter so we could all play with individual screens). 

A quick glance at their menu, an iPad touchscreen that you can navigate and order from, showed a variety of nigiri, rolls, hot and cold appetizers, noodles, donburi, skewers, and desserts. They even had sashimi plates, which sometimes seem to get omitted from bullet train sushi menus and was a plus for me! 

Despite our initial excitement, a few things brought our experience down from there.

First, prices in general were expensive. Second, quality was mediocre at best. You don't go to bullet train sushi expecting top grade fish, but the items were priced as if you were at a regular Japanese restaurant - for example, the 15 piece sashimi platter was nearly $30, yet the cuts were underwhelming in size and taste, and cold as well, as if they had just been frozen not long before. A small unagi donburi was $14 and mostly consisted of rice. The nigiri ranged from at least $3 for mostly non-fish items, to $4.50 for the usual maguro, and up to $8 for fatty tuna. Compared to when we are at Kula, which charges up to $2.75 for basic nigiri, we were much more careful and restrictive regarding choosing what to order. 

Finally, the bullet train system was not as advanced as others that we have seen - there were only two rows of trains, and you had to press a button manually to return the train to the kitchen. With a lot of people sending multiple orders, this could cause some back-up. There was also no disposal slot for finished trays, which resulted in more clutter at your table. 

One perk was that we got a "prize" screen every so often after ordering a certain amount of food, and choosing the correctly colored treasure chest rewarded us with a complimentary mochi dessert, which was cute...but didn't save the whole experience. The service was pretty good and our water was refilled and empty dishes taken on a regular basis. However, the amount of money we spent between two people seemed outrageous for the quality and quantity of food, and would likely have been better spent at a nice Japanese restaurant.
author: Brittney K.

description:
3.5 STARS

My first thought upon walking into Hikari: "Wow, my kids would love this!"

Except, I have none.

But, IF I had kids, I would bring them here....

"Sorry, no $100 Omakase for you until you get a job but look over there at the train - your $2 cucumber maki roll is here! Enjoy, while mommy knocks down several bottles of sake". J/k but I love this mommy's style: https://bit.ly/2HqxOSd. 

Several days ago, I read on Hoodline that there was a new sushi restaurant in J-town, Hikari that touts themselves as being the first bullet train sushi restaurant in the San Francisco. I immediately checked Yelp and saw they got raving reviews...but I should of read google reviews too because my friend and former yelper, Albertino M's review was on point: https://goo.gl/maps/xUQHMaFcCht. Hikari is really a hit or miss.

Before getting into that, let's talk about how Hikari works. Walk in, get seated, then start ordering on the iPad: https://bit.ly/2HgRjz5. You can only order 4 items at a time and you can denote what order they come in. Your order will arrive shortly via "bullet train". Pick up your order, then hit the red button, and the bullet train returns to the kitchen. 

I ordered the following: 
*Chicken Karaage ($6): https://bit.ly/2EDDepS
*Zuke Sake Nigiri: Marinated Salmon (2 pc - $4.50): https://bit.ly/2JCkpHj
*Aburi Sake Toro Nigiri: Seared Salmon Belly (2 pc - $5): https://bit.ly/2JzsZGO
*Aji Nigiri: Horse Mackerel (2 pc - $5): https://bit.ly/2HaORtZ
*Uni Nigiri: Sea Urchin (2 pc - $8): https://bit.ly/2IK15GV
*Otoro Nigiri: Fatty Tuna 2 pc - $8): https://bit.ly/2HuvREA

(+) Super sweet staff.
(+) Fast service, I was in and out in less than 20 minutes for lunch because it was completely empty. 
(+) Easy ordering process, unless you're one of the dinosaur senators questioning Mark Zuckerberg at the committee hearing. They would think the iPad was a painting. 
(+) Fun for kids, they will enjoy seeing their food arrive via the bullet trains.
(+) Large variety of non-cooked and cooked items: soups, salads, cold apps, hot apps, nigiri, maki rolls, udon, yakitori, and lunch plates.
(+) Reasonable prices. Nigiri pairs: $4 - $8, Lunch specials: $10-$11, and Udon/Soba: $6, etc.
(+) Otoro was the best cut - super fatty and melted like butter (albiet thin). 

(-) If you're looking for good sushi, this is not the place. The shari (sushi rice) is flavorless and the fish is low quality. 
(-) Zuke sake, aburi sake toro (they forgot to sear it), and aji were all stale and very dry.
(-) Inconsistency in shari (sushi rice) and neta (fish) sizes. I'm not trying to be nitpicky but the differences were very noticeable when lifting the neta up. Also, you can see the cuts widely vary in the Yelp pics. 
(-) Chicken karaage had a hard, chewy batter.

I'm in the minority here but even though Hikari was reasonably priced, the food was 3 stars at best (and that's being generous). I wasn't expecting great sushi for the price but I was bummed that the fish was stale and dry. For a good value, Amami is hard to beat. 

IMO, Hikari is strictly a novelty sushi restaurant for families with kids. Since I don't have any, unfortunately, it's unlikely I would return. 3 stars plus .5 star for the sweet staff but rounding down.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Date & Time:  Tuesday April 10, 2018 @ 6pm
Sushi Date:  The Husband
Scene:  Solo Diners, Couples & Groups in SweatShirt Dresses, Sneakers & MCM HandBags
Music:  Come Together 
Decor:  Contemporary & Whimsical.  Choice of Booths or Counter-Seating, Order on Individual Tablets & Sushi Comes Out in Record Speed on Rocket Boats.  Really Fun & Gimmicky as I Hop Up on The Booth and Press All the Buttons & Tug on The Boats
Service:  Super Cute, Friendly, Attentive
Imbibe:  Tea.  Beer, Sake & Flavored Teas Available
Devour:  Kumamoto Oysters, Chawanmushi, Aji, Tai Tororo, Aburi Toro, Hotate, Tsukune, Zuke Salmon, Negi Toro, Otoro, Udon Ebi.  Must-Try Desserts:  Kinako Warabi Mochi & Matcha Warabi Mochi
Total:  $84.28
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
Was in the area for the Cherry Blossom Festival so I decided to check this place out. Man oh man was I SO disappointed. It was definitely overpriced for the quality. We only ordered three things after scrolling through the ipad menus. We figured we'd eat somewhere else after since we didn't like most of the selections they had to offer. I got a roll with eel, egg, and some other stuff in it. It was just okay. My boyfriend got some spicy salmon roll which was mostly rice... there was barely any fish in it at all. I guess the only good thing we had was the udon, but it was pretty standard in flavor and needed a lot extra of that orange seasoning.

I loved the idea of getting my sushi delivered to me on a cute little train, but that's all it was - cute. It wasn't as high tech as Kula in Cupertino. There was no place to dispose of your plates immediately. You had to push a button for the train to go back rather than it immediately going back once it sensed the plates were removed. What if we never pressed the button, what would happen? There was only one train that would deliver sushi to the whole row of people besides you. I could definitely see this being a problem in terms of wait time...

The only reason why this place gets a two stars is for the service. The servers were very nice, but I would not come again or recommend this place if you're looking for something to fill you up. Kula is better in terms of price and efficiency!
author: Sydney C.

description:
Overpriced, mediocre, and a LONG wait time. 

It's a cool concept that will definitely draw crowds in - ordering on an iPad and waiting for your food to come out on a cute little train. The only problem is, there are only two trains per row that can only hold so much, serving at least 10+ people. At one point, one of the trains got stuck and a server had to push it manually... 
This results in a very long wait time and you can order only 4 items at once. We waited over 30 minutes to eat 4 pieces of nigiri and another 20 minutes for our sushi roll to come out. It got to the point where I was so hungry and impatient that I didn't even want to wait for the roll anymore and just leave, but the server insisted that it was still coming. 

When the roll finally came, it was nothing special and totally overpriced. For $13, the Hikari train roll is just a California roll topped with assorted fish and a raw quail egg in the center of the plate atop a bed of raw onions. The "seared and marinated" salmon nigiri ($4.50) was also disappointing, it wasn't seared at all and the slice of salmon was super thin. The other nigiri we ordered were hamachi, amaebi, uni, and unagi. These are all normal priced at $5-8 so if you're expecting prices like Kula Sushi in Cupertino, this is not it. The only thing that was worth the money is the uni, at $8 for two pieces. 

Overall, don't come here if you're hungry or in a group because you'll probably end up waiting for over an hour just for mediocre sushi. You can't even order it all at once! I get that they're new and probably still working out the kinks but that can't justify my terrible experience here. Our total for 6 items was already $54 and we left hungry because we didn't want to order more food and have to wait even longer. Pass on Hikari!
author: Cecille W.

description:
A real nice homey restaurant to get your Japanese fix...

First time experiencing bullet train sushi and definitely had a great time. For the price that you're paying - you get a lot of good value. I would not come here expecting amazing high-end fish because that's not what Hikari is about, but definitely worth what you're paying for.

A dish I pleasantly enjoyed was the chicken meatballs on a stick; was nice to break from the norm of just exclusively ordering fish.

Service was attentive and the restaurant is well kept. A great spot for any occasion with lovers and friends. ;)
author: Sam K.

description:
We didn't intend to come here but walked up and immediately reminded us of Kula Revolving Sushi restaurant.... it's not. 

There is no river of floating sushi. Their concept is you order on iPads. You order nigiri, rolls, mini udon/soba bottles, appetizers and drinks. The sushi and rolls speed to you via "train." You take your food off of the train and then press the red button to send the train back.

The food is ok, the concept is different and it's on the above average price range. 

Now that I've been here once, I don't need to come back.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
I was excited to try the novelty of this place! This restaurant has such a great concept, but the food was average. Nothing really blew me away, except seeing our food arrive on cute little bullet trains. You order on an iPad, so you never really have to talk to a server. However, boyfriend ordered 4 of the same dish, so we actually did have to call someone over to fix that. You can't fix it on the iPad once you press "order." I tried the chicken karaage, eel and avocado sushi, and the salmon shioyaki dinner. I would say the food was pretty bland, but everything was cooked perfectly. 

The servers were really nice and did check up on us. Our waters and teas never hit bottom. :)
author: Rachel H.

description:
A new restaurant in the Japantown area that has great potential, but some "touch up" still in progress. The concept here is a "bullet train" type delivery. Customers sit next to a carousal. Currently (subject to change) you order the food on an iPad that's fixed-mounted too high that's also positioned very hard to access. Once you order (up to four dishes), the food is delivered via a bullet train to your dining area. You pick up your order, hit a button and send the train back to the kitchen.

The sushi quality is on par from others but there wasn't any "daily specials". Lot of the rolls were also not available. The choices were not as great as some of their neighbors, but for the items they do have, it's pretty good. Their Udon noodle size are single small portions and their tempura batter was fresh and light.

I did get a chance to meet the owner. He's actually a very nice and friendly guy who welcomes feedback. He's aware of the iPad ordering challenge and in the process of getting menus and portable tabletop kiosk. I think once he fix this this will be a great spot
author: Eric T.

description:
First time coming here and it was great! We came right at opening so we didn't have to wait too long. The waiters were friendly and let us choose between sitting at a bar or booth. 

You order on iPads and every individual has their own tab. The food is all quite reasonably priced and delicious. Would come back here again!
author: Helen z.

description:
Sushi rice here is really not good.  Its over cooked and the cook doesnt know how to cut limes for some of the sushi.  The lime rinds are kind of thick and hard to eat.  Ankimo came out warm, sushi rice temp varies and is not consistent.  Very dissapointed.... Also at the end, the owner mistakenly charhed me 4000 dollars for. 40 dollar meal...  Of course he corrected it, but with all the dissatisfaction involved, this was just the cherry to my "sad sundae."

The guy who says that this place is good.....  Id question all his recommendations....  This place is absolutely not good.  It's clean, but its not good.
author: James Y.

description:
There's many improvements this place can make. I came here with my family and oh boy this place is overpriced. Nigiris were on average $4.00 for two. The slices were not consistent. The tako (octopus) was so thin and sad looking. The rolls were around $12, which is okay. But if you're going to get rolls, it's better to go else where because this place does not have much to choose from. 
At random (I think), there was a game where you choose a treasure chest. I was so confused. We chose one box and then there was a notice that our "price" was coming. We got the mochi ice cream, but only one. 
The servers were kind. The waiter came back to refill our teas and timely took away our plates. 
Right now they have lunch promotion, which is 20% off Mon - Thurs at 11:00. If you want to try this place, I would take advantage of that promotion.
author: Kiyomi K.

description:
Great for small groups. Fun concept. The more you order, the more likely you are to get a prize--a treat on the house. Fun little incentives great for kids and again, small groups.

Fish quality was alright. Nothing special to rave about here. This place is more for the experience than the quality of food. Service was pretty good. For a busy Saturday night, the staff were very attentive to the best of their ability. It was a packed house. 

Highlights were the appetizers. Hamachi kama and salmon Kama were delicious. Huge portions worthy of sharing with a table for 3-4. Appetizers come piping hot, looks as though nothing sits out for long. 

Overall, fun concept. Great to bring friends and small families.
author: Michelle C.

description:
For fresh sushi and fun Japan Bullet Train Serves, why would anyone pass up on this?!? They have bar seating for party of 2s to large tables for party of 8s.  The sushi took a while to come so you know it's made at order.  The sushi is place on bullet trains from kitchen to arrive at your table.  Then you take the food from the bullet train and push a button to send the train on its way to return to the kitchen.  For the very clean people, the sushi is covered with a lid.  It's very interactive.  Highly recommended.

Price is comparable to other places, so I didn't feel anyway overpaying. 

Clean place. Clean bathroom. 

Nice staff and quick serves for Saturday dinner.  Great job staff!
author: Lynn W.

description: Best dining experience ever! I was strolling for something different, found it! Glad I entered bc I thought the environment wouldn't be comfortable for lonely me on Friday night. Def a gem for solos dining next time I will bring my guy along to binge without guilt/regret. I can sense Japanese style here, service is excellent and attentive. The small portions are really really nice esp in America is quite rare. The sake are just right goes down well and I can walk well! Custard are... well delicious! Reasonable prices well low. Beyond and above.
author: Linio F.

description:
Bullet train sushi restaurant in SF, say whatttt? 

Came here Monday night around 7pm, there was no wait. 

I got the Cherry Blossom roll ($12) and it was alright. It was tuna, salmon & avocado. The fish was not too fresh, and the roll was pretty small imo. 2 piece nigiri started at $4 for 2 pieces. 

I mean the concept is cool. Order from a tablet, items shoot out of a cool bullet train (JR?) Oh how I miss Japan! This reminded me of Genki in Japan, and Kula/Kura which is the same thing but cheaper and more options. There's a bar side where each individual will get their own tablets, which by the way was way too high up EVEN FOR MY TALL FRIENDS. I swear it's not even because I'm so tiny. Then there's tables where you can sit together and order on one tablet. I think it's more fun to get to use your own and order your own, so we opted in for the bar. 

The food came out randomly and was quite slow, even though the restaurant was quite slow. 

The experience was cool overall, although I'd probably would opt out of coming back. It's fun to get to do this but food wasn't spectacular to say the least.

Update: they charged me the wrong amount on my credit card.... look out on your bank statement. I'm taking off another star
author: Melody W.

description: No wait on a Saturday night at 7 pm. The bar seats were all open and our group opted to seat at the booths. The bullet trains were initially very exciting to watch but they became distracting over time. One of the two trains that were serving food along the booths became broken, and we had to manually push them back towards the kitchen each time a table took their plate. The food was not bad for sushi boat quality, and the menu offered many appetizers and sushi rolls in addition to nigiri. However, the sushi rice was not great and kept falling apart.
author: K. N.

description: I haven't been to a train sushi place since I went to Japan, so I thought I'd try this place for fun. It's decently quality and priced sushi with extremely fast service. This isn't gourmet sushi by any means, but definitely worth it for the price and the fun factor. I've been three times in the last few weeks.
author: Cynthia M.

description: Wanted to try the first bullet train Japanese restaurant in SF.  The staff was friendly and welcoming.  Everything is ordered on an iPad from noodle soup, sushi, appetizers, sushi, sashimi, drinks, and dessert in which you can order four at a time. I like the concept and the food came out quickly with short wait time.  I felt it was a bit pricey compared to some sushi places but it was good and people came in and out fast.  Overall, a nice experience.
author: FG L.

description:
I was so excited to try this place because I was really craving sushi.  We got seated right away but our food took forever.  Our 2nd order came before our 1st order.  The customer service was okay I just didn't understand why the food took so long when it should be fast for a conveyor belt sushi restaurant.  Overall, I wasn't quite impressed.  

Ordered: chanwanmushi, various sushi rolls, chicken katsu
author: Mikayla M.

description: Paid about $50 for two people, definitely not worth it. I had better from other sushi places with the same concept. Their sushi was definitely not fresh and tasted worst than sushi from those Chinese sushi buffets which are pretty bad. Salmon tasted crunchy and hard while slimy which was pretty bad, glad we didn't get sick.
author: Elizabeth L.

description: I loved this place!! We had such a great experience here! The food was delicious! I highly recommended the dragon roll sushi, the soft shell crab and the mochi ice cream. Yum! The staff was friendly and took the time to explain the menu. Love this place. If we're ever back in San Francisco we will definitely be eating here
author: Jinel G.

description:
Hikari,  you have the honor of receiving my 700th review.  I've been lazy lately, and when i heard about the opening of this place, i was excited to try it.  I've been noticing the construction of this place for about a year and was glad that they finally opened. I've seen a couple of these restaurants in Asia, so it's cool to see the first one in SF.  It's right across the Peace Plaza and when you walk in, it's actually pretty spacious. Hikari is actually a train line that takes you from Tokyo to Osaka, so i think the name of this place is actually pretty fitting.  They have long tables for party of 4 and 6 and they also have bar side seats for couples or individuals.  

The way this restaurant works is that, you order from a Ipad and you are allowed to order 4 items at a time.  The menu comes in 4 different languages, English, Japanese, Korean and Chinese.   From the menu, you'll have your choices of Nigiri, Gunkan/rolls, appetizers, noodles(soba/udon),  Rice/Yakitori, drinks (beer, wine, ice tea, soda and etc) and specials(desserts).  They give you a pen,which makes it easier for you to select your items.   After your selection, you place your order and the red light at your station will light it, indicating that your train with the food is arriving soon.  When it arrives, it beeps.  You remove your items from the train and press the button so it can return to it's main station.  The concept of this is to cute, I saw a lot of kids around me having fun with this, but as a grown up, I was having just as much fun. I got super excited when the train arrived, I felt like a kid again. 

So let's get to the food.  As I said earlier, they have Nigiri options.  What i love about the screen is that they have broken up the nigiri options into sections.  They broke it down by Maguro, salmon, Whitefish and etc.  which is great when you only want to eat a particular fish.   I ended up ordering the Salmon, Zuke salmon, Hamachi, Uni, Aburi toro, scallop and kanpachi. All of these were pretty fresh, my favorite was the zuke salmon and the hamachi. The scallop was also my favorite because it tasted sweet and the portion was good. But the most amazing dish of the night was the Carpaccio, which had the right amount of sauce to go with the salmon and scallop.  I finished the dish as fast and if i had more room in my tummy, i would've ordered 10 more of this dish!  It had the melt on your mouth feel when you were eating it. My friend got the Chicken katsu with a bowl of rice. The batter was perfect and it was just fried to perfection. Not too dark and not so hard where it was too crispy.  

Overall, i enjoyed my visit at Hikari.  What i also enjoyed seeing was they they had a great selection of ice teas, they had mango green tea, Passion fruit black tea and much more.  The service was super nice and i spoke to the owner and she mentioned that they are still working on the menu, and will be adding more items.  I will be back for more food once they add more items!
author: Belinda C.

description: Been waiting for a long time for this concept sushi spot and it has finally opened. You order from the display screen above the table, scroll thru the iPad and click away and then be sure and press order. Moments later a tray of sushi slides out of the wall with your order. Don't forget to press the red button to return the empty trays back.
author: Brian J.

description: It's a fun place to go and try a new way to eat sushi, high-tech combine with food, it's a good experience. I'm so enjoying​ the moment when the train brings​ the food to my front. Speak as food quality, it's an Ok level, not very recommended​.
author: Faye L.

description:
This was the first time eating hear after a friend mentioned this restaurant to me. Everything we ordered was delicious. The fish was very fresh. My favorite was the Hamachi sashimi. It was very fresh. To describe the flavor can only be compared to eating the finest butter yet crunchy. The udon was delicious. I did like the 49er roll and the Lion King roll. If you like a hint of spicy, this is the roll for you. It wasnt the type of spicy where your mouth was on fire but made its presence known and then quickly disappears. I would highly recommend going, especially if you are a sushi/sashimi connoisseur. I was lucky enough to meet the owner, Vin. He is very nice. 

The service was amazing as well. The cool thing is that your food arrives on a Bullet. Which was cool. You dont have to worry about your order sitting to be brought out to you. It comes to your table right after it is made. We had the fried giant squid, and it arrived at our table right after it came out of the fryer so wait a little bit before taking a bit.
author: Serene W.

description: Super fun sushi place to bring the family. Great for kids and fish is actually very good.
author: Auren H.

description: I am really pleasantly surprised by Hikari!! I was expecting this place to have overpriced terrible sushi and be only popular for the the gimmick... and don't get me wrong, the gimmick is great but the sushi wasn't bad either! Ok this will not compare to sushi fresh flown in from japan but for around $4 for an order it was still fairly fresh and tasty. They also have sushi which is slightly seared which I absolutely love... also! They had otoro for like $8 which is not bad at all compared to many of these higher end places! The uni was also fine and not terrible. Other main cooked dishes were around 11 ish and so all in all, you could have a very good meal for not too bad price... also the trains!! I will definitely be back!
author: Jocelyn K.

description:
I had high hopes for HIkari after having been to similar restaurants in the South Bay and Hawaii.  It is good to see this kind of restaurant in San Francisco.

Unfortunately, there is no wow factor with Hikari.  Sushi was pretty much average, prices are a bit on the high side, and the bullet train system is probably the same speed or slower as having a waiter or sushi chef bring it to you.  Definitely, it is not as fast as the other restaurants I've been to.  Also, similar restaurants have a greater selection of other offerings such as mini rice bowls, poke, and so forth.

This is a new restaurant so they have growing pains and have some areas that they could improve at.
author: Re-pley Z.

description:
The fish are make to order and very fresh. 
I personally know the chef and he is very good at making sushi that I personally like.

I see reviews that says that food takes awhile, it's true but in the end it's all worth it. Why you may ask?! They use their time preparing fresh food ready to serve from scratch! 

So when you guys see all these bad posts about this place it may be fake! My son is a little chef and he loves cooking, he loves sushi a lot and he knows about what is fresh and what is not. And if he says it is fresh, I believe him!

In the end this place is worth my time and wait!
author: Stanley F.

description:
The current 3.5 yelp rating of this place is accurate. No health hazard. But also inartfully crafted. For example, tekka maki is a very standard dish. The finished product here looked as if I had taken a stick of room-temperature butter and squeezed my fist until lumps fell out between my fingers. The fish was visible, and not just from the ends of the roll.

I'm not sure who cut the sashimi either. They cut it in exactly the opposite direction it is supposed to be cut. Sashimi should break apart easily as you chew. That has to do with the chef using the proper technique to cut the fish in the right direction. It tasted like whoever prepared our sashimi had never sat down and eaten at a sushi restaurant before.

They also didn't seem to get the concept of the train they so well advertised. I understand that we front-loaded a lot of our order, but the concept is to serve us as the food is prepared one dish at a time. Not make us wait 20 minutes to prepare the dish that likely takes the longest to prepare--chawanmushi (by the way, did the pour the whole bottle of yuzu juice in there??? That being said, consistency of the egg was interesting)--simply because that was the first thing on our list. And also, don't serve the other 6 dishes all at once. Prepare the fish for one dish, send it out, then start preparing the next dish. Again, it felt whoever was serving us had never been to an automated sushi restaurant before, let alone Japan.

All things considered, it's been over two hours, and I've experienced no...digestive problems. Again, the food tasted okay, but there was just no soul behind it. That's quite a front when you stiff us with a $50 bill for two when we could have had a more enjoyable experience that was more diligently prepared at other restaurants for a fraction of the price. If management were wondering, that's why there's not a line out the door, even in SF which loves gimmicky restaurants and activities.
author: JWest M.

description:
I went on 4/21/18 when Hikari was still new. It has a pretty standard sushi and sashimi menu along some rice dishes, yakitori, appetizers, and rolls. Also saw a good selection of sake and non-alcoholic drinks. Its not gourmet sushi but it was solid. I went when it wasn't super crowded and everything I ordered was fresh, hot, made to order and delicious. 

Their natto nigiri was on point. 49er roll was also fresh and delicate. Aburi Salmon Toro Nigiri was also yummy. I paired a shrimp and veggie tempura appetizer (perfect crunch) with Niku Beef Udon. The bullet train delivery is super cute. I ordered enough food to unlock a gift which was a free green tea ice cream mochi. The staff were all super nice and attentive. Definitely coming back!
author: Claudia L.

description:
Everything was fresh and well made for a casual lunch spot. Restaurant was clean and not busy for Friday lunch. Service was quick and I love the efficiency of the iPad menus and novel
bullet train delivery. Is it the best sushi ever? No. But the prices are reasonable for what you get and I enjoyed it. Will be back again soon!
author: Courtney Y.

description:
I found this place out while waiting in a longer than expected queue at the sushi boat next to the book store. Hikari was decently good. I would compare it to the rest of the sushi boat places but a bit more clean and everything is made to order.

You order from a tablet and wait for a bullet train to swing by. You are limited to four orders at a time and the food ranges from nigiri to rolls and to more hefty meals. Once the meal comes it sounds a beeping noise. After grabbing your dish you hit the button to return the train.

Unlike most sushi boat spots in the city bringing a toddler isn't much of an issue since sitting in a booth can enjoy the bullet train magic.

Food was as expected but service was great!
author: Benny S.

description: I was recently in San Francisco for my birthday and this is one of the places we stopped by to eat at. It was such a fun experience! Everything is convenient, and the food is great! I recommend the vegetable gyoza and poke salad as appetizers they were delicious. Definitely plan to make another visit.
author: Alondra C.

description: Wow this was so much fun!  My kids have experienced the original ipad sushi experience in Tokyo and we were hoping to find it on our Japan cruise.  We could not locate it during our online research and our cruise cancelled a port due to typhoon so on our return to SF we wanted a memorable sushi meal.  We were willing to settle for conveyor belt but my search led me to Hikari which offers ipad/bullet train sushi.  What does this mean?  You use an ipad at your table to browse the menu and place your order.  You can take your time and order a few items at a time and keep adding more items.  When ready, a little whistle blows and the screen changes.  Unfortunately, it is in Japanese for the message but a picture shows you what is being delivered to the table.  Then you watch the track to see the little bullet train deliver your food tableside.  You are then prompted to remove your items and then press the "return" button to send the train back to the kitchen.  It is such a simple but clever idea!  The food was good and the experience extremely memorable.  I will definitely return when traveling on business in October.
author: Maria K.

description: I ordered the mini tempura udon ($6.75) & unagi hand roll ($4). Udon was great, although the tempura that was served with the udon had way too many onions and shrimp tasted like it wasn't cooked fully. My first impression of the tempura was, what is this concoction? I would imagine the typical battered long shrimps and not a mash of everything. Hand roll was okay. I wanted to order more things but there wasn't a lot of items on the menu & it was kind of pricey. My friend ordered the unagi roll & another roll, the vinegar was too strong on the unagi roll. I was excited that this was the first bullet train restaurant but it is lacking a few things..
author: Suki L.

description: The location is great and everything is well put together. As for the food, it's low quality and expensive. You're better off going into the Japantown building for better food.
author: Manuel V.

description:
So freaking cute. The goober loved it and we got a kick from the adorable little trains zooming to and fro. The food is pretty good. Decent sushi fare with some mini dishes/bar fare.
Knocked out a star because the restaurant could have been cleaner. For something that's fairly new it's showing signs of neglect already (dirty dishes and dirty floors).
author: Miwa W.

description:
Honestly phenomenal. I never write yelp reviews but this place was so good I had to. I've eaten at a lot of the great sushi places in SF but this one was very surprising. The sushi is nothing short of impressive and the bullet train sushi is a great novelty. The otoro was fresh and make sure to have a mochi ice cream at the end.

Minimal interaction with any humans all you order your entire meal on an iPad and check out whenever you're ready.

I can't wait to go again!
author: Danny F.

description:
Pretty bad sushi with a smart gimmick, not a place to make a regular visit. 
There's only 2 rails so orders kept going to the table next to us because they kept sending in orders nonstop. Kitchen sent us the wrong order twice but insisted it was the right one. Not to mention everything is terribly overpriced.
author: Shermond W.

description:
Food was great, fun atmosphere. Would recommend:

-miso soup
-salmon nigiri
-hamachi kama
-unagi nigiri
-maguro (tuna)

Lion King roll was good but could use more sauce. 

4 stars because it's a little pricey (ours was $30pp)

Would definitely come again!
author: Leland F.

description: The nigiri was alright. They also have natto, which was pretty good! The chicken karaage would be great if it was seasoned. We got a free warabi mochi, which was cool. I didn't try any rolls, but maybe next time I will. There's minimal interaction required with your waiter/waitress since you order on a tablet and the food comes to you in the train. However, the employees were very attentive with tea refills. The trains are pretty fun, and I'd say it's worth checking out.
author: Jackie L.

description:
The food is 3 stars. 

+1 star because I enjoy the minimal amount of human interaction I have to endure here.
author: Sabrina M.

description: Randomly popped in here.  Looked like it might be bad.  It was a quirky gimmick with the trains and the ordering system, but I was pleasantly surprised by the food.
author: John S.

description: Sushi is good, but the beef teriyaki is the worst I have ever had.  It was not even chewable and I had to spit it out.  I had my husband and brother both tried it and they agreed it was not edible either.  By the way it was $18!!!
author: Eugenia R.

description:
Went here as party of two during the soft opening. I live nearby so I've been anticipating this place opening for months! 
Overall this place is good if 'the experience' ranks higher than the actual food. This place has been very nicely renovated- clean and modern decor. 
While this is one of the first bullet trains style sushi places in the US, they are commonplace in Japan.
I personally like shinkansen bullet train style better than kaitenzushi revolving sushi bar style (places like Kula) because the sushi is made to order rather than sitting on the conveyor belt. This should mean fresher fish for the customer! (Also less chance of getting sick and less food wasted) 
However, if you are a sushi snob and into omakase style, this place isn't for you. But if you want simple nigiri sushi, rolls, and general Japanese food in a nice setting this is a good option. 
I can see this becoming a big tourist spot for Japantown. It's great for families and kids. Everyone can get something they want. There are A LOT of non sushi options. The dessert choices were pretty solid too.
However, BEWARE the food quality compared to price was a bit expensive. The quality was just ok. The rice was a bit dry and underseasoned and the fish quality was average. You are ultimately paying a premium for the experience.
author: Summer B.

description: First, I dont care much about the bullet train food delivery. It is like just wow for 2 secs n that is it. Now the real deal: food I ordered 6 piecese of sashimi. Those are the bomb: fresh, sweet and big. Next meal I ordered is beef teriyaki. It is deliciously good w/ good amount.  For the price I would say it is reasonaly high. I definitely come back and hope that today is not just only my lucky day here.
author: Sanguan L.

description:
I went here for soft opening day with my 3 years old. Very kids friendly, nice service and fun!! Food was great. Highly recommended! 
If your kids love trains, they will have so much fun here!!
The restaurant is clean and spacious
author: Nahoko D.

description: I feel like I'm back in Tokyo at this fun sushi restaurant. Surpringly good quality fresh seafood. The only thing more fun than ordering by iPad is watching the food arrive by high tech shuttle. Everything was super fast and delicious. Very friendly staff. I wish all restaurants offer you button to request a server or to get the check. I highly recommend this futuristic sushi place.
author: Eric O.

description:
Well well well. What do we have here. This place finally opened across the street from the japantown plaza (I think opened for less than a week). Entered a dainty little place if you ask me for a similar conveyor belt/ sushi boat sushi concept but miniature style. Once you walk in, you can't help but noticed a bunch of iPads readily available to take your orders. After getting seated you'll wonder how come the ordering screen's so high up and hard to reach (for the shorter arm folks). Don't be silly like us loosing our blood flow just trying to place orders! There is an iPad pen provided to help you out!! We forgot about it Dx 

Very self explanatory ordering system. Varieties of categories to choose from and you just add what you want to your cart by selecting how many quantity of the order you would like. You'll notice fairly quickly that it's limited to 4 pieces per order since it'll let you know you won't be able to place another, once your order come, you'll be able to place your next one. I'd say the selection was alright. Not too many choices but also enough for you to browse. Would recommend adding more selections in the future once you gauge more with your customers.

Price I must say it was a bit above average for what I'm tasting. We're looking about ~$3-10 per order (comes with 2 pieces each). 

Onto the food portion, it's fairly decent in my book. Have I had better for this type of concept sushi? Yes. Have I had worse? Definitely. It's kind of just in the middle where it's alright. Definitely not a place I would wait in line for (like the revolving sushi place in Cupertino formally known as Kula Sushi but now renamed as Kura Revolving Sushi). Oh and not to mention the color of their plates reminds me of the ones from Kura as well, except they don't have a plate disposer for games. Tried out the hamachi, salmon, unagi, and marinated salmon nigiri, their $2 kumamoto oyster, and their hamachi Kama. As you can tell, wasn't all that exciting for us to try only a number of things before we *ahem* hopped over to Benihana to catch their happy hour because their food were more worth it and filling for their price. You're literally just sitting next to a straight conveyer belt where the food goes back and forth like a train. BUT, do recommend to try their hamachi Kama, made just right.

Overall fun concept, maybe more suitable for family and kids. Personally, I tried it, experimented, checked it off and don't think I would return anytime soon. Not my cup of tea but thanks for the warm and cute service!
author: Aly C.

description:
Interesting, each tables has screen to order the foods (this might not special), but the foods are served by Bullet Train, this is unique. 
Foods are ok, Beef tetiyaki well done cooked. We love the experience more .
author: Maria S.

description: I've been waiting outside for 30mins because of the Cherry Blossom Festival. It wasn't too bad. All the sushi tasted ok, none of them surprised me. Two of us spent over 80 dollars, that's a little bit pricy.
author: Welcome Z.

description: From a creativity aspect, this place is like a 5. We can order our dishes right from our seat on an iPad like machine and then there will be "bullet trains" that deliver to your seat and take the trash back. Very innovative but also at the same time hard to use for first timers. I know I accidentally checked out after ordering. The food is average also, nothing really stands out. So depends on what you like, this place can be a hit or miss.
author: Junda P.

description:
I really love this place;)
Highly recommend  

The price is not expensive, good quality food and
Excellent service!!!!
author: Praewnapa A.

description:
partial "FNO" (fam bam nite out)...wanted to try this month new spot...

N U T S H E L L . . .
familiar concept of sushi ordering on individual ipads w/ "bullet train" rail delivery...eh quality & $$$...aiight to try the novelty once if u haven't done it elsewhere, but i won't reco otherwise...

i had already read that ppl compared it to Kula/Kura in south bay & east bay who is a LOT cheaper (my review @ www.yelp.com/biz/kura-revolving-sushi-bar-cupertino-3?hrid=Jvm1FZ8Dvi9J59cxj0EoUg&utm_source=ishare )...

T H E  F E E L . . .
single-seat counter on left facing the wall w/ its own speed rails...4-top booths in the middle row...6-top tables & a couple 4-top booths on the right...all food delivered on a couple rails after u order thru ur stationed ipad...4 max ea send...drinks, noodles, tempura, etc delivered by servers...

T H E  G R U B . . .
* Tako Su (octopus salad), 6.  |  whole slices w/ pickled cucumbers & seaweed...pretty chewy...
* Spicy Hotate (scallop), 6.  |  not spicy tho...
* Sashimi Combo (tuna, salmon, yellowtail), 12.  |  fam bam thought mushy...but it met my low expectations...
* Carpaccio (5pc salmon & 4pc scallops), 15.
* Otoro (fatty tuna), 8.  |  eh...
* Zuke Salmon, 4.5  |  seared...uh, don't think it said that cuz i wouldn't have ordered it...
* Aburi Salmon Toro, 5.  |  buttery/smooth, but not the best quality...
* Ikura (salmon roe), 6.  |  standard
* Madai (sea bream), 5.  |  nothing like what i had elsewhere...
* Amaebi (sweet shrimp), 7.  |  lil mushy w/ no DF heads...
* Ankimo (monk fish liver), 7.  |  standard
* Tsukune (chix meatballs), 3.  |  skewer of 4...diff, i likey, but fam bam thought funky...
* Tempura, 7.5  |  4pc shrimp w/ assorted veggies...
* Soba Niku, Mini (buckwheat noodles w/ sliced beef), 6.5

ordered these, but never came & yet it read "served" on the ipad list...had to tell waiter to remove them...
X Philly, 7.
X Cali Roll, 6.

i didn't taste these, but here is fam bam's feedback...
* Shishito (peppers), 2.5  | not spicy
* Uni (sea urchin), 8.  |  mostly brown = poor quality
* Hirame (halibut), 4.
* Hamachi Kama (yellowtail collar), 12.  |  x2 cuz it was the best thing...

T H E  "D R A N K S" . . .
* Shouchikubai Hot Sake, 5.
* Passion Fruit Green Tea, 3.5

O T H E R  D E E T S . . .
the ipads r positioned too high...our arms got tired tryna look thru the menu pages & order...nvr had that prob elsewhere...

the trains got stuck & seemed malfunctioning many times...we told the staff when ours wouldn't go back & they asked every table to help push them along to return to the kitch...or nothing else could come out for anyone...

prize award possibilities...idk what activate their trio treasure chest game onscreen, but we got it 4x...picked losers first 2x, but won the latter couple...mochi ice cream came on the speed rail shortly after...

T H E  S E R V I C E . . .
they were well-staffed & attentive, which was good...but some of the waitresses weren't fully knowledgeable & kept asking the males to help...no biggie...

C O N C L U S I O N . . .
dropped almost 2 bills for 3ppl!...1 salad, 10 nigiri, 2 sashimi, 1 skewer, 1 veg, 1 app, 2 kama, 1 tempura, 1 mini soba, 2 drinks, & 2 mochi ice cream prizes = 20 food items...got full, but imo, Kula/Kura quality...

again, aiight to try here once for novelty sake only...otherwise, there is much better quality at this price point in jtown & all over da city...we coulda had better w/ AYCE sushi & cooked items @Tao for 1/2 that... (my review @ www.yelp.com/biz/tao-sushi-san-francisco-6?hrid=Qc6N8mYuVocDnBqu5F5Mhg&utm_source=ishare )...or Sakana Bune for cheaper sushi boat conveyor...

not to mention, 5hrs later now, my tummy still feels uneasy & has been for the last few hrs!...
author: Nettie S.

description:
Came here yesterday around 5pm - they were pretty full but no line. We ordered the spicy tuna roll, tuna roll, salmon avocado roll, tuna nigiri, marinated tuna nigiri. I think the average wait time for each roll or order was about 5 to 7 minutes. Of course, they came out on these cute bullet trains that stopped in front of us and once we take the dishes off, we can send the bullet train back to the chefs in the back by pressing the red button in front of us. We ordered using the tablets set in front of us. There was also a button that we could push if we needed server attention. One of the downfalls of this place is that they had some of the Main dishes labeled as sold out, such as fatty tuna, so we were limited in the things that we could order which was very disappointing.
Inside was pretty spacious and comfortable. Service was pretty good for the most part except for when we first came in and no one acknowledged us for the first 5 minutes although the same waitress had been walking back and forth passing us and never once looked up to greet us or acknowledge us. That was a bit disappointing but other than that it was pretty decent service.
I don't think I would come back but if you're looking for something interesting or cool to try out such as the bullet train Sushi then I think it's good for a first time. However, if you are really looking for Quality sushi, experience and service then I think it's best to go elsewhere.
author: Hu L.

description:
I usually don't write reviews (just a few so far).  But I want to write about Hikari because the staff is nice and I really want this place to thrive.  

The bullet train is really for the kids.  I came with my niece and nephew.  (2/3 of the people there came with kids too.)  But when you sit at a large table (for 6), there's a reach issue when it comes to ordering.  There's only one screen by the food delivery area and since the kids wanted to see the bullet train deliver the food up front and personal, they sat by the order screen.  This in turn created a big issue in which the grown-ups had to reach over the kids to order.  Every. single. time.  And the people on the far side could barely see the menu (two seats over) and did not have access to ordering food themselves.  I think orders per table would increase dramatically if there is another order screen on the other side of the table.  Also, the downtime between ordering was boring to the kids as they kept wanting to see the bullet train come out so it would be helpful to have more games on the screen to entertain them (then the adults could perhaps use another screen to order?).  I understand that this is additional cost to the restaurant but since there are only a few (I think six?) tables, I think the incremental revenue would make it a worthwhile investment. 

There's a good variety of Japanese food so it's not just sushi as many in my family do not eat raw food due to personal preference and allergies.  As the same time, you shouldn't come here expecting sushi that tastes like they just got flown in from Tsukiji Fish Market. Portions are on the smaller side but this actually works well in this setting because we got to try many different things (i.e. a mini chicken udon is only $6).  

Like other reviews had stated, sometimes there were a few items that took quite a long time to come out and the kids got anxious ("Where's the train?").  

Staff was attentive and friendly and really tried hard to make our visit as comfortable as possible.

This restaurant doesn't take reservations so we went early and was able to grab a table without waiting at all.  

Overall it was a good experience for the kids and the food was decent enough for the adults.  I would recommend this place if you have young kids (10 or under).
author: Isabella F.

description: The bullet train was fun, the sushi was average to good. The price however makes one believe that the sushi should be better or at least more plentiful
author: Jon I.

description: Cute concept and design, and attentive service, too. I loved the seaweed salad. The miso soup and salmon avocado roll were fine, but not special. I ordered a glass of the Bonecrusher Zinfandel (which I've had at other restaurants and loved), and it was served ice cold, which is very sad because you can't smell or taste it when it's served cold. I would bring friends here for the novelty, and because the people working there were so nice.
author: Phoebe O.

description:
For me, this was good sushi, good price, good service and good old cheesy fun!  

The BULLET TRAIN.  You order on an tablet that's hooked up on the table.  When you press order, you wait for your food to arrive via the BULLET TRAIN that will stop in front of your table.  As you wait, the bullet train may deliver other food to other people, so sometimes you get all excited, just to watch someone else's food pass by.  But, eventually, the train will stop in front of your table, and you'll pick up the food, send the train back and dig in!  

You can order in multiple rounds, but be wary, if you explore the menu too long, your arm will start to hurt as you explore through the options.  Still fun though.  

We ordered an avocado roll, salmon sashimi, a rock and roll and an edamame.  All of which was really good.  The whole thing came out to be around $30 with a nice tip, which is totally reasonable for SF.  And it came with hot tea, which I loved. 

The line was non-existent when I went on Sunday afternoon, you can press a button to get service and the servers were great, and the bullet train while a little cheesy was totally fun.  As we were about to leave, a family with kids sat down, the kids were so excited to see the bullet train come out with their food.  I think my reactions were the same as theirs, so, fun for kids and childish adults!
author: Cristina C.

description: Mediocre sushi and very expensive. I have to go out and eat something else after spending $15 on lunch here. I don't find the experience is worth the money.
author: Sharath C.

description: Not worth the hype.... the food was pretty good and the fish tasted fresh but prepare to wait 15 minute for 1 dish to come out at a time. We ordered way before the other 2 tables yet ours are the last to come. Cool concept and servers were nicr but I don't think I'll be returning here anytime soon, we stopped ordering just because it took an hour and 15 just to get 6 dishes out
author: Jeffrey X.

description: This place is not$$ I think it should be listed as $$$. Quality is average, long long wait after we press the button to order. Over priced in my opinion. Hope they will improve but after this first time I had a bad experience I don't think I will come back
author: Gregory L.

description: Good sushi. Not five star but good. Bullet train was awesome. Kids loved it. Good value for the dollar. Sushi snobs look elsewhere. Budget conscience sushi and yakitori lovers rejoice.
author: Girlie G.

description: Service was quick and friendly! Sushi tasted great at great prices, we'll be coming again.
author: Lisa L.

description: This place is mediocre (2.5 stars). Fun place to try, but if you are a sushi lover, this is not the place for you. You are allow to order 4 dishes at a time, and service is very slow. It took 30 mins for our first dish to come out. Uni was 'yack' - taste like cheese.
author: Zee Z.

description: Staffs are friendly, sushi is good, the space is wide enough, I'm so glad that this store finally opened, think it'll become my favorite sushi bar in Japan town;)
author: 泥絲

description: Really fun place to experience and the food is pretty good too! Avocado rolls are totally bomb, and the seaweed salad was nice and fresh!
author: Mariah And Myles ..

description: Suuuuuper slow service. Ordered 3 rolls about almost an hour and still havent received it. The food is alright but a bit pricey for the portion. I'm mostly annoyed at how incredibly slow the sushi rolls are coming out. The waiters are nice though.
author: Rose G.

description: We went this sushi place thinking that since it's in Japan town it must be decent....however, the quality of fish was very bad and very little selections... and the price is not cheap either.  Just because my kids enjoyed bullet train brings your sushi, I gave 2 stars....oh and they serve jasmine tea instead of regular green tea....
author: S K.

description: The food wasn't great, the sashimi had a fishy taste which indicates that the fish isn't too fresh. They also got one of my orders wrong but I didn't want to correct them because it already took them 25 minutes to get it to me. The bullet train conveyor belt was cool but that's about it. The food is subpar, and maybe I went in with high expectations but the entire experience was underwhelming. I would say come here for the experience, but don't expect too much from the food.
author: Tiffany H.

description: I came here on a Saturday for lunch. The line was pretty long, but I didn't have to wait too long to get seated. The concept of this restaurant is pretty unique where they have a bullet train that brings your food. iPads are provided at each table for you to order your food. The service was decent and I felt that the food was alright. Overall, I feel that the only great thing about this place is the concept of the bullet train system.
author: Maggie T.

description: Great concept and amazing eats! In town on business mixed with fun and ran across this place by accident. My girl friend was getting her lashes done and we arrived early to find out we where in the Japanese Center so we decided to give Hikari a try. Touch screen ordering and sushi delivered on a trolley right to your table. Sushi was amazing and will definitely come back the next time we are in San Francisco!
author: Yancey G.

description: Very nice and clean, the service was good and quick. The sushi was fresh and tasty, no complaints at all. I will definitely be back for more next time I crave for Japanese food. Highly recommended!
author: Jessica Y.

description: Great new sushi place! Service is friendly, really cool automatic delivery, high quality fish, and the rolls are priced super well.
author: Chris F.

description: Amazing!!! Excellent service and the food was out of this world! You have to stop in and try this place and you will be so glad you did! Keep up the great work!
author: Todd D.

description: I came in because it reminds me of Kula Revolving Sushi in Cupertino. I found out from the owner that this place has opened for just two weeks and he said it took two years to remodel. For a revolving sushi place, it is quite comfy.  I like the privacy I had sitting at the booth. Food was good. The steamed eggs was so good!  We liked the scallops, sweet shrimps. The sushi here is way better than Kula but it is more expensive here of course. The iPad we ordered from flashed out 3 Treasure chests in the middle of our dinner. We picked one and got a prize! We didn't know what it was until the dish of seaweed salad stopped next to us on a bulletin train. I took one star out because the placement of the iPad was too high and my friend who sat next to the button got very busy.  She had to press that  button to return the bullet train back to the kitchen after every dish. The button is also high up.  Imagine stretching your arm during the entire dinner! But this could be a good thing if you have kids who need to do something.  We really like the owner. After we told him how we didn't like the placement of the iPad, he unlocked it and just made the iPad portable for us. He even sent us a free mochi dessert on a train. He knows he has a lot of things to work on. He's a very humbled guy. I really like him!
author: Tina L.

description: Fun atmosphere and the sushi was actually really good!  Great place for kids too especially if you get a booth.  Reminds me of japan
author: Anne E.

description: They are really new. So the wait staff doesn't quite know how to explain the ordering system to new customers. The quality and freshness of the fish was very good. For the price great quality. I especially like that unlike other conveyor belt you don't get a toy for your prize, you get food. Much better
author: Todd C.

description: The concept is very cool, but the execution isn't great. Some fish were hit or miss, and the speed of items to the table was slow. I will say that the toro was great along with the scallop. Rolls were good but very loose and took forever. I would rather go to normal conveyor belt sushi as there seems to be a larger selection and more convenient.
author: Brandon R.

description: Waited 15 minutes for 4 nigiri. Left after that. This place is overpriced and not worth the wait.
author: Ronald L.

description:
The service was great. The food was very good.
Hamachi Kama is very fresh and good.
Sashimi was small portion but tasted fresh.
Gyoza was a large portion, hot and tasty.
Pork tonkatsu was very good too.
We dined on a Tuesday night so no problem getting a table.
Comfy booths. 
It's a fun concept, for$60 we both ate and drank and left satisfied. I would return
author: Suzette J.

description: Nice and clean. Finally in this area have a big place for you to enjoy sushi. For the price not too bad. Foods are good. Will come again
author: P L.

description: I love this place! It's right down the street from my work so I'm a regular. So quick! Great service. They are so nice and accommodating they always make me rolls without rice when I'm being carb conscious!
author: Amanda M.

description: Superb! This unique restaurant exceeded my expectations. The food is delicious and reasonably priced, delivered to your table bullet-train style moments after selecting from a tablet menu.  Conveniently located across the street from Japantown mall and parking lot. I highly recommend this place for those looking to get some good Japanese food in SF.
author: Tim Y.

description: We were rooting for you! WE WERE ALL ROOTING FOR YOU! I really wanted this place to succeed but it was a huge fail. Tried to come in at 1pm for lunch, locked and closed even if it supposedly closes at 2:30pm. I shouldn't have went back for dinner. Workers there were friendly and attentive. We were seated quickly. Having never been there before, I thought servers would instruct on how things worked. Didn't. However, it's kind of straight forward (except the fact that you need to manually return the bullet train post-arrival). Ordered 3 things to start... 3 small plates and about 40 min later (roughly about 25+ min of which was waiting for those plates), the bullet train niche was not worth it. With booths filled, my party of 2 sat in the empty bar area, where service for food was clearly neglected. Quickly got our bill and bounced. Sure, it's new and sure whatever "give it a chance" and I guess taste wise is alright but I don't see how it can be successful even if it was better organized. Hypothetically, if the bar where I was sitting in was packed (about 20 seats or so) and there are literally only 2 trains that could run at once AND you have to manually push a button to return each time, no one would get their order in decent time or maybe even correctly. Even on a day where there is 2 people at the bar, the bullshet train takes a longer wait than the muni and that's saying a lot. In conclusion, it's a no from me.
author: Emily M.

description: Fun sushi bar with fresh sushi and other Japanese "go to's" delivered to your table on a bullet train.
author: Rob M.

description: We loved the bullet train delivering items.  All the food was good.  Great for kids!  I liked the small puddings for $1.50.  Will return.
author: Kathy K.

description: Very delicious, I always love to eat sushi and this is the best of the best. Resturant staff is friendly and the wait time is short.
author: Ruudy L.

description:
When: Dinner service on a Friday
Cleanliness = (5); pretty clean but granted it just opened so you would hope so.
Wait = (4) : Put our name down and waited about 30 mins. It's in a great location where you can explore a bit and come back when around when you think it's time.
Food= (2) : budget quality; didn't get me sick but didn't taste great either.
Service = (2) : took a long time for a food to come, also hard to wave down servers despite not having to serve food.
Price = (3): decently priced for what it is.

Setting, Seating, Wait: 
Came in on Friday night around 7ish. Didn't have to wait long (30 min) since it's sort of new, but I'm sure it'll be tough on the weekend. Place seats pretty well. 12 booths and maybe 16-20 at the bar. Pretty efficient with space. Also I don't think this is Japanese-owned. Based on my experience, Japanese-owned sushi restaurants usually will provide you with oshibori. Being that I'm Chinese, I overheard the staff + manager/owner speaking Chinese so I'll leave you to judge for yourself. 

Food: 
Few key things: ordered Uni, Ikura, Otoro. Uni was no good. It didn't come in nice big pieces and it didn't taste fresh. Tasted very metallic and not very fresh. Ikura tasted very bland and alarmingly warm. Otoro's texture was a little firm but was decent. Did a quick peak of the kitchen through the window and it looks like one Japanese sushi chef just supervising a group of non-Japanese food preparers, which brings up my second point. 

Service: 
Restaurant was pretty packed when I was seated (by the bar). Each section (bar + 2 rows of booths) has two tracks- up and down- each with a train housing two plates. I don't know if it's inexperience or an understaffed kitchen or poor design, but food was not coming out as fast as it should. I'm not surprised however. The menu has nigiri, rolls, tempura, rice dishes, noodles, dessert. The kitchen probably had maybe 10 people working and trying to fill 50+ orders coming in all at once. On a busy night, expect to wait for about 30-45 minutes for your order to start arriving one at a time. We didn't see the train come out more than 7-8 times before we saw our food- so 30 minutes, maybe about eight orders. Also there were about 4 people working front of the house- seating, bussing, working the POS. Wait staff was very friendly though- when you can get their attention. I think the owner skimped big time on the staffing thinking the trains will cut out of most of the labor requirements. Big mistake- I think they should address that issue quickly, especially when it's still new and first impression is huge in this city's restaurant industry.

Price: 
I don't think the quality was that great for the price you're paying. Very gimmicky concept so that's where you're paying the premium for the experience. I could tell the owner invested a lot of money on the concept and the design of the restaurant but skimped on the food quality and the logistics. For the price, I'd rather go across the street to Nijiya and get better quality product, but I digress.

Cool/cute experience to impress a date (unless he/she can distinguish good sushi from bad then no, stay away!), but not a place I would bring my parents or friends. I wish them the best of luck and I hope they succeed. I'll probably return a few months from now if judging by the reviews they've improved. For now, it seem like it's not all there.
author: J C.

description: Great sushi, awesome service, and the food is delivered on a conveyor belt. Great experience in Japantown!
author: Missy H.

description: Cute idea - you order in an iPad and your food is delivered to your table on a "bullet train" tray on a conveyor belt. The food was fine but nothing special, though, so not sure I'd come back.
author: Katie B.

description: San Francisco's first bullet train sushi bar.    A fun place with solid sushi and sashimi that is delivered to you by bullet train.
author: Mark K.

description: Kids can order sushi via iPad which is delivered via bullet train. The food was great and the train kept my daughter entertained.
author: Peter S.
